awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  A Body Area Sensor Network with Smart Glove Base Station for Improved Physical Therapy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will provide a low-cost wearable Internet-of-Things (IoT) device for upper extremity physical therapy rehabilitation. The project will contribute to the ultimate goal of helping patients suffering from stroke or joint-related injuries of the upper extremities. The project will result in a body of knowledge that physicians can leverage. For example, Fugl-Meyer assessment (FMA) scores can be computed from the acquired sensorimotor information to assess the physical performance of a patient. Our innovative body area sensor network with smart glove base station (BASN-SG) design can be used to track and speed up the patient recovery process by promoting neuroplasticity through biofeedback. Thus, providing both the physician and patient a quantitative tool for upper extremity rehabilitation. Outreach opportunities will be pursued through local middle schools to use this BASN-SG technology to generate student interest in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) topics. The project also has a huge commercial impact and has a potential to lower the health care and labor cost associated with neurological rehabilitation of stroke patients by over 30%.

The proposed project aims to develop and commercialize a novel BASN-SG design that leverages an award winning and patent pending IoT smart glove device to measure the sensorimotor information of the human hand, which is not possible through alternative means, e.g., smart phone. Furthermore, the smart glove will be exploited for secure centralized processing of the sensitive biokinetic and physiological information that will be wirelessly transmitted from the BASN. Conducting sensor data fusion and processing closer to the body will address issues associated with signal propagation and multipath, packet loss due to signal interference and noise, cyber threats due to network attacks to foster physician-patient confidentiality, and energy consumption of wireless sensor nodes. Our research objectives includes: (1) developing a wearable exercise shirt with built-in modular wireless sensor nodes for acquiring the bio-states of the user to be transmitted to the smart glove base station, (2) algorithms on the smart glove to enable conducting sensor data fusion and processing closer to the human body, and (3) a virtual reality software tool that uses the aggregated and fused data set from the smart glove base station as an input controller for user biofeedback.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
According to the 2019 update report of the American Heart Association (AHA)[1], each year over 800,000 people suffer from stroke or joint related injuries, which makes it the leading cause of permanent disability in the country. Patients seeking treatment will need to first meet with their primary physician, who will refer them to a physical therapist (PT). Treatment involves one on one sessions with their therapist, which aims to (1) regain motor function, (2) reduce pain, and (3) prevent injuries and disabilities. This STTR Phase I project proposed and successfully created a novel body area sensor network (BASN) for improved physical therapy by aggregating multiple interconnected nodes, on a human body, for sensorimotor measurements. Our BASN solution, is a wearable internet of things (IoT) device or namely a Wearable-IoTTM device, which has been shown to provide a patient with quantitative measure of progress that currently does not exist in the practice of conventional physical or occupational therapy. Without any quantitative data, the patient may face motivational challenges when improvements are subtle and gradual. Furthermore, without knowing the details of progress, it can be difficult to set and reach goals, for example a goal to improve wrist rotation by 5% within 6 months. Moreover, combining the aggregated data with instantaneous visual or audio feedback will promote neuroplasticity while speeding up the recovery process. In this STTR Phase I project, we  were successful in the design of a Wearable-IoTTM that will consist of a mesh of network smart multimodal sensors, each with plurality of sensors including, ranging of motion, electromyography (EMG), electrocardiography (ECG), temperature and (newly developed) acoustic sensing, which is fundamentally different from the state-of-the-art in sensing solution for P.T. rehabilitation.

 

This project resulted in a novel Wearable-IoT system that can be used as a bio-feedback tool for improved physical therapy. Our novel solution solves the problems with existing solutions by creating a wearable system that employs a network of smart multimodal sensor nodes, each with a suite of sensors that allows for acoustic cardiography (ACG) and acoustic myography (AMG), in addition to sensors for Electrocardiography (ECG), electromyography (EMG), temperature and range of motion. In Phase I, we only demonstrated ECG and EMG, however with the addition of our acoustic sensing we have the potential for ACG and AMG.

 

Our solution has also result in a body of knowledge that physical therapists can leverage. For example, Fugl-Meyer assessment (FMA) scores can be computed from the acquired sensorimotor information to assess the physical performance of a patient. FMA is a metric commonly used by therapist to assess the sensorimotor impairment in individuals who have had severe joint-related injuries, arthritis, acute/chronic pain and stroke, it includes scoring for motor function, sensory function, range of motion and more. Having a uniformed mechanism for quantifying the physiological and Biokinetic states of a user during exercise sessions will provide a platform for acquiring and analyzing sensorimotor information, while improving post assessments in physical therapy sessions. The project also has a significant educational/scientific impact.

 

[1] Heart disease and stroke statistics – 2019 Update American Heart Association
